The curriculum includes courses that cover UAS regulations, operations, applications, and hands-on flight experience, ensuring graduates are well-versed in both the technical and operational aspects of sUAS.
Program name: Minor in Small Uncrewed Aircraft Systems (sUAS) Operation

description:
Students will gain an understanding of how space systems are designed, operated, and integrated into complex space missions. Graduates will be prepared to contribute to the operation of spacecraft, ground systems, and space-related activities in both government and commercial sectors. This minor provides students with knowledge, skills, and abilities for a career in the space industry focusing on operations.

The Space Operations minor requires 15 credit hours of coursework covering orbital mechanics, spacecraft systems, space mission operations, and space policy and law. Students will learn about the current state of the space industry, its challenges, and opportunities. The minor also provides hands-on experience with space mission design and simulation tools.

The Minor in Space Physics is an excellent option for students pursuing a degree in a related field who want to broaden their knowledge with an understanding of space physics. Space Physics deals with the study of plasma processes occurring in the space environment, particularly in the Earth’s magnetosphere, ionosphere, and the sun’s corona. Space physics is an emerging field with many opportunities for graduates, especially in space weather, where space events affect technological systems on Earth and in space.

The Minor in Space Policy, History and Culture, offered through Embry-Riddle’s College of Arts and Sciences, allows students to explore space as a social, political, economic, and cultural phenomenon. This 15-credit minor focuses on the complex nature of human interactions with the space environment, equipping students with a multidisciplinary understanding of space activities. Students will examine space exploration from various angles, including its historical context, ethical implications, and global governance frameworks. The curriculum covers topics such as international space law, space security, commercial space ventures, and the cultural impact of space on society. Students will learn about space history, policy, law, culture, and ethics. They will analyze historical and contemporary issues in space policy, evaluate the geopolitical and socioeconomic impacts of space activities, develop critical thinking skills to address complex challenges in space governance, and engage in interdisciplinary research on space-related topics. This minor prepares students for roles in space advocacy, diplomacy, policy analysis, and related fields, enhancing career prospects in government agencies (like NASA, NOAA, Department of State), aerospace companies, think tanks, non-profit organizations, and international organizations (like the United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs). It complements a wide range of majors, including aerospace engineering, aeronautical science, homeland security, and global security and intelligence studies.
Program name: Minor in Space Policy, History and Culture

description: The Minor in Space Studies program at Embry-Riddle is designed for students seeking to broaden their knowledge in space-related disciplines. This program offers a unique interdisciplinary approach, drawing from various fields such as astronomy, engineering, space law, and policy. Students will explore topics like spacecraft design, orbital mechanics, space exploration, and the legal and ethical aspects of space utilization. This minor is ideal for those passionate about space and looking to enhance their primary degree with specialized expertise, preparing them for careers in the growing space industry or further academic pursuits.

The Supply Chain Management in Aviation and Aerospace minor prepares students to understand and integrate current supply chain technologies and management systems in the aviation and aerospace industry. Students will gain knowledge in areas such as procurement and sourcing, logistics and distribution, quality control, operations management, and supply chain analytics. The minor complements various degree programs by providing a specialized understanding of supply chain principles critical to the aviation and aerospace sector, enhancing graduates' competitiveness in a rapidly evolving global market.
Program name: Minor in Supply Chain Management in Aviation and Aerospace

description: Systems Engineering is an interdisciplinary field of engineering and engineering management that focuses on how to design and manage complex systems over their life cycles. As a systems engineer, you learn to oversee the complete life cycle of projects and products, from concept to production, operation, and ultimately, disposal. You will learn to integrate the knowledge of all technical disciplines, including software, hardware, and human-factors engineering, into a coherent whole. Systems engineers work with various industries, including aerospace, defense, energy, healthcare, and transportation, and are responsible for ensuring that all components of a project or product work together seamlessly. The Systems Engineering Minor is an excellent option for any student interested in learning about the interdisciplinary aspects of designing, developing, and managing complex systems over their life cycles. This minor helps prepare students for successful careers in various industries, including aerospace, defense, energy, healthcare, and transportation.

The Technical Intelligence minor prepares students to analyze technical data and synthesize intelligence information from publicly available and classified sources. Students learn the analytical process for identifying, collecting, exploiting, and disseminating technical intelligence about foreign weapons and space systems. The interdisciplinary curriculum focuses on analyzing technical intelligence data with applications to national security and commercial applications. The minor provides a multi-domain analytical framework that focuses on advanced technologies such as cyber, artificial intelligence, unmanned and autonomous systems, hypersonics, and space systems. Students will learn the collection and analytical tradecraft required to support the intelligence community, federal law enforcement, and national security agencies.

The minor in Technical Management provides the business management expertise necessary to effectively manage engineering and technology-oriented programs and projects. Students will gain an understanding of principles such as organizational behavior, financial management, marketing, and the legal and ethical issues related to operating a business in a global environment. This minor is an excellent complement to technical and engineering degrees, providing students with the skills needed to lead teams and manage projects effectively within a technical field.

Terrorism is a serious threat to national and international security. With the Minor in Terrorism Studies program, you will develop an understanding of the historical, political, and cultural factors associated with terrorism and counterterrorism. You will also learn about the policies and strategies for combating terrorism. This minor is open to all students at Embry-Riddle’s Prescott and Worldwide Campuses.

Embry-Riddle’s Uncrewed Aircraft Systems Applications minor focuses on the practical application of UAS and their integration into various operations. From basic UAS operations to advanced remote sensing technologies, students will learn to operate UAS in a safe and legal manner while gaining an understanding of the impact of UAS on society. This interdisciplinary minor allows students to apply these technologies to their primary field of study, enhancing their marketability and giving them a competitive edge.
Program name: Minor in Uncrewed Aircraft Systems Applications

description: As UAS technology continues to evolve, so does the demand for qualified operators within various public safety organizations. From law enforcement to search and rescue, UAS are becoming indispensable tools for enhancing situational awareness, improving response times, and increasing overall effectiveness. Embry-Riddle’s Uncrewed Aircraft Systems (UAS) in Public Safety Minor provides students with the knowledge and skills necessary to effectively integrate UAS into public safety operations. Whether you’re pursuing a career in law enforcement, emergency management, or firefighting, this minor will provide you with a competitive edge and prepare you for a rewarding career in an increasingly important field. The curriculum covers a range of topics, including UAS operations, regulations, data analysis, and ethical considerations specific to public safety applications. Students will gain hands-on experience with UAS platforms and software, developing the practical skills needed to deploy and operate UAS safely and efficiently in real-world scenarios.
Program name: Minor in Uncrewed Aircraft Systems (UAS) in Public Safety
